Muller is ormally inaugurated
By DON LASSUS
In a brief, simple ceremony
Dr. Steven Muller was
inaugurated yesterday as the
tenth President of the Johns
Hopkins University.
A capacity crowd of faculty in
academic robes and well-dressed
onlookers filled Shriver Hall to
hear the series of short speeches
that characterized the one hour
ceremony.
The bright television lights and
incessant flashbulbs commonly
seen in Shriver were absent from
the proceedings which broke
away from the tradition of
elaborate inauguration
ceremonies.
Adverse Odds
In his inaugural address to the
University the new president
4.1 spoke with confidence of the
future course of Hopkins,
Dr. Muller: "We can survive each other only if we deal with each other... recognizing its problem
s and
always as human beings, not as categories, hierarchies, or abstractions."
difficult solutions.
"We are pressed to make large

THE HOPKINS

NEWS'LETTER

decisions that will affect us all,"
said Muller.
Pointing out the advantages
and drawbacks of a small, private
institution such as Hopkins
Muller stressed the continuing
pursuit of excellence despite
"adverse odds."
No Blueprint
• Muller defined his function in
the University as "part
conscience and part spokesman."
"Since I can offer no blueprint
for the future, I pledge myself to
offer what assistance I can to the
process of decision-making which
we cannot avoid," he stated.
Muller listed issues of
immediate concern to Hopkins
which included defining the
mission of undergraduate
teaching, preserving the
traditional research basis of the
University and operating
effectively under a limited
budget.
Concerning the issue of
governance Muller commented,
"We must govern ourselves so
that no voice is stifled nor any

interest ignored, but also so that
administration is as simple and
effective as possible knowing that
within a university
self-governance is a means to an
end, not an end in itself."
Muller also recognized the
University's responsibilities to
the community as an institution
but emphasized individual
involvement.
"Our mission is teaching and
research, not social action,"
Muller asserted.
He termed Johns Hopkins a
"deeply human organism"
requiring cooperation between all
parts to function productively.
High Morale
A resolution was delivered by
Robert D. H. Harvey, Chairman
of the Board of Trustees, praising
Dr. Milton Eisenhower for his
services to the University as
interim president. Harvey listed
among Eisenhower's
accomplishments "the renewal of
purpose, direction and high
morale which pervade the
University community."

the news-letter is published twice each week during the school year by
the students of the johns hopkins university, homewood campus,
baltimore, maryland. editorial and business correspondence should be
addressed to box 1230, the johns hopkins university, baltimore,
maryland, 21 21 8; telephone 301-366-3300, extension 1308.
subscriptions $8 per annum. member, columbia scholastic press
association.

the installation
Yesterday's pomp and ceremony was somehow
refreshing, a reaffirmation of our existence as an
institution. The installation of Steven Muller did seem to
mark the continuation of the pursuit of excellence,
unfettered by administrative incompetence and
directionless leadership. Dr. Muller's refreshing candor
dominated his inaugural message which showed his deep
insight into the University. He rightly steered us back to
the road of daring so necessary for greatness, and it is
noteworthy that the first problem that he asked the
community to tackle was undergraduate education. But
Dr. Muller seemed to back off when he defended the
traditional role of the University as a socially inactive
institution. In its pursuit of excellence, Johns Hopkins
needs to be brave enough to critically examine the
relationship between the university and the society and to
change that relationship if necessary. Otherwise, the
growing problems that modern civilization faces might
make a small, private university an expendable luxury, and
soon a thing of the past.

Planned Parenthood of Maryland
EDUCATION COMPROMISE
To the Editors:
Dr. Walton's recent action in
his continuing struggle to
reinstate the Education
Department has certainly
brought the question to the
surface, but if the past is any
prophet, he will largely be
ignored.
It seems evident that the

THAT PJA
COTERTAitJfrat

MD INC GC)00 6045
CATal THEM OP
MEM.

411. /
:: (f'
# _, —

administration will not
re-establish the Education
Department anytime in the near
future on any basis which has
thus far been proposed: setting
up a full-scale graduate
department is certainly a large
undertaking. To date, however,
the undergraduate need has not
been mentioned. Although the
current undergraduate needs are
met by the Evening College, the
little bit of red tape and the
inconvenience of evening classes
is undesirable.
Perhaps what we need is a
compromise department, one
that would offer only a very
basic course of study which
would be sufficient to meet most
state accreditation _requirements.
Such a department would be very
limited and not terribly hard to
implement, and it would meet
whatever undergraduate demand
there was without causing the
administration to become
apoplectic.
Will Fastie

To the Editors:
I would like to commend the
News-Letter for printing a public
service ad in the February 15th
edition that tells the whole story
about the availability of abortion
in Maryland and emphasizes the
fact that there are indeed
non-profit referral and
counselling services right in
Baltimore.
Profit-making referral agencies
have proliferated in the wake of
abortion law reform or repeal
throughout the country. These
agencies were outlawed in New
York by Attorney General
Lefkowitz last summer, but they
continue to flourish in
Pennsylvania, Maryland and
Washington, D.C. The agencies
advertising in the Hopkins
News-Letter and other college or
hip papers in this area have been
tested by Planned Parenthood
staffers. Although the degree of
sensitivity in the voice at the end
of the line did vary, the basic
'message stated by each agency
was "send us the money, and
we'll tell you where you can go
for an abortion." Little
attention, if any, was paid to the
uncertainty that the tester
expressed about having an
abortion, or in fact, whether or
not she was even pregnant. And
with the exception of one case,
when the agency was told that
the caller did not have any
money and was literally begging
for another resource that would
do the abortion for a lower price,
the caller was told that she would
have to get the money or get no
abortion.
And the.money: the fees were
anywhere from $25 to $100
higher than the going rates at
hospitals and free standing
clinics. In addition to this,
misinformation was very
common. When asked if there
was a free Clinic or a Planned
Parenthood in the city of
Baltimore that could help the
staffer who• was posing as a
scared college girl, she was told
that either she could only go to
Planned Parenthood if she were

feb 23, 1972/news-letter/page 3

Reading clockwise from top left: Robert D.H. Harvey,
chairman of the Board of Trustees, confers the Presidency of
the University to Dr. Muller, as Dr. Eisenhower prepares to
invest him with the presidential insignia; Dr. Muller gives his
inaugural address. On his right is the historic cane chair given to
the University by the Harvard Club of Maryland, a replica of
the President's chair of Harvard College; Dr. Muller and his
wife, Margie, greet guests at the reception following the
ceremony; Chief Marshal A. Edward Maumenee carries the
Presidential Mace, an ebony staff decorated with silver which
represents the role of the Arts and Sciences in man's cultural
development.Photos by Daniel Epstein.

page 4Inews-letterifeb 23, 1972

Muller becomes Hopkins' youngest president
Dr. Steven Muller, forty-four
years old, is the youngest man to
become Hopkins' president since
Daniel Coit Gilman took that
office nearly one hundred years
ago. Muller has spent much of his
life in university campuses.
With the exception of two
year's duty in the Army Signal
Corps, he has been connected
with a university—in one way or
another—since his undergraduate
days at UCLA. His university
experience has ranged from
undergraduate to his new post as
President, filling virtually every
slot in between.
He graduated from UCLA in
1948, travelling to Oxford as a
Rhodes Scholar, earning a B.
Litt. degree in 1951. Muller then
returned to the United States and
enrolled as a graduate student in
political science at Cornell.
In 1958, after two years in the
Army and a two year tenure as
assistant professor of political
science at Haverford College, he
received his Ph.D. from Cornell.
He joined the faculty of the
Cornell Government Department
that year. Many of the faculty
with whom Muller was associated

at Cornell felt that he had
foresaken his academic ability
when he turned from teaching to
administrative duties, one of his
former colleagues said. He served.
in the Cornell administration for'
nearly ten years.
InternationakStudies
In 1961, Muller took over as
director of the Cornell's
Vice-President for Public Affairs
during his last five years at the
New York school.
It was in that position that he
came to national attention during
the "Straight Crisis" at Cornell in
1969. Muller served as a
negotiator during the
confrontation which saw armed
students occupy the student
center. He was widely praised for
his actions at that time.
Muller came to Hopkins in
April, 1971 as Provost of the
University. During the nine
months before his election as
president, Muller served as
assistant to interim President
Milton Eisenhower.
During his days at UCLA,
Muller met his wife-to-be, the
former Margie Hellman. While he
studied at Oxford as a Rhodes

Med Plan to bring
community action
By MICHAEL BERKE
Dedication of the East
Baltimore Medital Plan medical
and dental clinics, Sunday, marks,
the Medical Institutions'
participation in affairs of the
local community.
The medical plan is operated
by the Johns Hopkins Medical
Institutions and the East
Baltimore Community.
Corporation. It provides prepaid,
group practice health care for
residents of Latrobe, Douglass,
Lafayette and Somerset Homes
housing projects.
Dr. Rogers, former dean of the
medical school ,.spoke at the
dedication at St. James and St.
John Roman Catholic Church,
Eager and Aisquith streets.
Rogers told a crowd of about
one hundred that "the
microcosm of East Baltimore is
representative of the health care
problems of inner cities."
"You who will work in the
center will have the spotlight
shown upon you," Rogers said.
The clinic will be a model for
solution of health care problems
in inner cities in the United
States.
"Obstacles to creating the
health care program were
formidable," he stated.
Defects in Mechanisms
"The negotiations you went
through reveal "appalling defects
in mechanisEis for financing
health care," Rogers told the
board. "It made particularly
evident the problems for those
who are black and those who are
poor," he continued.
The board had to contend
with five financing mechanisms
and twelve agencies' financing
restrictions in establishing the
center.
"A group of concerned human
beings learned to work together
for a common goal," Rogers said.
Residents of the neighborhood
surrounding the hospital and

executives of the Medical
Institutions are members of the
Board of Directors.
Do Say
"About three years ago I never
thought we'd get to the place
where we'd talk about each other
like that," said city councilman
Clarence H. "Do'. Burns, whc
presided at the dedication.
A ribbon cutting ceremony
and tour at the medical and
dental center followed the
dedication.

Scholar, she launched her career
in public relations, and they were
married in England in 1951.
While Muller was enrolled at
Cornell, she continued her career,
working as a free-lance writer,
advertising copy-writer, and
finally an assistant vice-president
of marketing for an Ithacarbank.
She is currently employed as
public relations officer for
Maryland National Bank.
Muller was born in Hamburg,
Germany in 1927. His family
moved to Los Angeles, California
in 1940, where he graduated
•as
from high school and entered
UCLA. His father, a lawyer and
judge in Germany, was employed

as a translator

Kunstler brings politics to Towson
Speaking to an assembly of
200 students at Towson State,
Monday night, attorney William
Kunstler called the trial of
Arthur Turco "disgraceful and
unfathomable."
Kunstler defended Turco in
the trial which ended last
Monday with the acquittal of
Turco on charges of ordering the
execution of a Black Panther.
Turco, who spoke to the
students before Kunstler, denied
that he directed the killing when
he allegedly told a Black
Panther, "Do what you gotta
do."
Kunstler charged the State's
Prosecuting Attorney Milton
Allen with "calling confessed" to
the witness stand and with
producing witnesses to testify
against Turco who were
previously on the payroll of the
Baltimore City Police
Department's Intelligence
Division.
Commenting on the charges
against Turco and the means

employed by the prosecution,
the lawyer who defended the
Chicago Seven declared, "This
city is guilty of attempted
murder. In any decent society,
Milton Allen would have been
indicted, and the failure to do so
speaks louder than words."
Kunstler termed Allen a
"disgrace to the legal
profession."
Calling for an investigation of
the Police Department, Kunstler
criticized Baltimore's "supine
public which allows itself to be
driven and bullied by officials
who cheat, lie and murder in the
name ofjustice."
He continued, "Law like this
should not be respected but
destroyed."
Citing the absence of any
editorial comment in the city's
newspapers concerning the Turco
"pseudo-trial," Kunstler
characterized Baltimore as "a
moribund or dying community
whose citizens are all guilty
because of their indifference."

Kunstler compared the
indifferent people of Nazi
Germany who countenanced the
atrocities of Auschwitz to
Baltimoreans who remain silent
in face of Turco's plight.
"Inhumanity"
Noting his sudden fame as a
"New York streetfighter with a
lawbook" Turco traced his
original dissatisfaction with the
legal system to the "inhumanity"
he experienced in the New York
jails.
Owen Fenn, a member of the
People's Party of Baltimore
circulated a petition at the
beginning of the evening in hopes
of attracting 10,000 signatures to
place a Peace and Freedom Party
candidate on the Presidential
ballot. Fenn's offices,where the
petition can be signed, are
at 1 East 25th St.
There was also a plea for a
barrage of letters to be directed
at the Iranian Embassy in protest
of the recent string of political
executions in that State.

Hopkins hoop win clinches playoff berth
By MARK LEIFER
Credit Blue Jay basketball
Coach Gary Rupert with working
his second miracle in two years at
Hopkins. Rupert's charges made
it official Monday night by
whipping Franklin & Marshall at
Lancaster, 78-64, to clinch a
third place finish in the Middle
Atlantic Conference Southern
Division, thereby earning a berth
in the loop's postseason playoffs.
Climax
The victory climaxed an
unlikely success story that bears
a familiar ring for Blue Jay
basketball fans. Two weeks ago
the cagers' season mark stood at
2-13, hardly an awe-inspiring
ledger. A recent run of four
straight conference triumphs over
Ursinus, Dickinson, Moravian,
and F&M, however, has boosted
the Jays' conference record to
6-3, despite an 0-12 slate in
non-league play. Ironically, the
squad was 2-11 last season before
shocking three-time defending
MAC champ Muhlenberg, second
place Lebanon Valley, and tough
University division foe Drexel in
succession to start their climb to
fourth place. Hopkins nipped
heavily favored Muhlenberg,

Scoring Punch
As a sophomore thrust in the
Jews, the 6'7" leaper from

however, and missed Saturday's
The same went for Bobby non-conference 94-81 loss to
Freedman, who had ball handling Western Maryland. Jews played

Monday night despite the pain,
against the Diplomats and
chipped in with 21 points.
Not to be overlooked by any
means is captain Gary
Handleman, the lone senior on
the team. Handleman, at 5'11",
might seem to lack the necessary
height to play forward, but his
performance hasn't shown it. The
leading scorer in Hopkins
basketball history, Handleman
needs but eight points tomorrow
night against Loyola to become
the first Blue Jay ever to notch
1,000 points. The contest will be
Gary's last home game in a Blue
Jay uniform.
Hopkins closes out its regular
season with a Saturday night
contest with Washington College
across the Bay. The Jays will
oppose host PMC. 81-76
vanquishers of Hopkins, in the
opening round of the MAC
playoffs March 3-4, while
Lebanon Valley, 101-68 winner
over the Jays, takes on
Dickinson, 97-68 losers to
Hopkins. Should the Miracle Men
slip by the Pioneers, Rupert
maintains he won't fear a
rematch with the Flying
Dutchmen. "We're strong now;
we may raise some hell up
there."

Muller is ormally inaugurated
By DON LASSUS
In a brief, simple ceremony
Dr. Steven Muller was
inaugurated yesterday as the
tenth President of the Johns
Hopkins University.
A capacity crowd of faculty in
academic robes and well-dressed
onlookers filled Shriver Hall to
hear the series of short speeches
that characterized the one hour
ceremony.
The bright television lights and
incessant flashbulbs commonly
seen in Shriver were absent from
the proceedings which broke
away from the tradition of
elaborate inauguration
ceremonies.
Adverse Odds
In his inaugural address to the
University the new president
4.1 spoke with confidence of the
future course of Hopkins,
Dr. Muller: "We can survive each other only if we deal with each other... recognizing its problem
s and
always as human beings, not as categories, hierarchies, or abstractions."
difficult solutions.
"We are pressed to make large

THE HOPKINS

NEWS'LETTER

decisions that will affect us all,"
said Muller.
Pointing out the advantages
and drawbacks of a small, private
institution such as Hopkins
Muller stressed the continuing
pursuit of excellence despite
"adverse odds."
No Blueprint
• Muller defined his function in
the University as "part
conscience and part spokesman."
"Since I can offer no blueprint
for the future, I pledge myself to
offer what assistance I can to the
process of decision-making which
we cannot avoid," he stated.
Muller listed issues of
immediate concern to Hopkins
which included defining the
mission of undergraduate
teaching, preserving the
traditional research basis of the
University and operating
effectively under a limited
budget.
Concerning the issue of
governance Muller commented,
"We must govern ourselves so
that no voice is stifled nor any

interest ignored, but also so that
administration is as simple and
effective as possible knowing that
within a university
self-governance is a means to an
end, not an end in itself."
Muller also recognized the
University's responsibilities to
the community as an institution
but emphasized individual
involvement.
"Our mission is teaching and
research, not social action,"
Muller asserted.
He termed Johns Hopkins a
"deeply human organism"
requiring cooperation between all
parts to function productively.
High Morale
A resolution was delivered by
Robert D. H. Harvey, Chairman
of the Board of Trustees, praising
Dr. Milton Eisenhower for his
services to the University as
interim president. Harvey listed
among Eisenhower's
accomplishments "the renewal of
purpose, direction and high
morale which pervade the
University community."

the news-letter is published twice each week during the school year by
the students of the johns hopkins university, homewood campus,
baltimore, maryland. editorial and business correspondence should be
addressed to box 1230, the johns hopkins university, baltimore,
maryland, 21 21 8; telephone 301-366-3300, extension 1308.

the installation
Yesterday's pomp and ceremony was somehow
refreshing, a reaffirmation of our existence as an
institution. The installation of Steven Muller did seem to
mark the continuation of the pursuit of excellence,
unfettered by administrative incompetence and
directionless leadership. Dr. Muller's refreshing candor
dominated his inaugural message which showed his deep
insight into the University. He rightly steered us back to
the road of daring so necessary for greatness, and it is
noteworthy that the first problem that he asked the
community to tackle was undergraduate education. But
Dr. Muller seemed to back off when he defended the
traditional role of the University as a socially inactive
institution. In its pursuit of excellence, Johns Hopkins
needs to be brave enough to critically examine the
relationship between the university and the society and to
change that relationship if necessary. Otherwise, the
growing problems that modern civilization faces might
make a small, private university an expendable luxury, and
soon a thing of the past.

EDUCATION COMPROMISE
To the Editors:
Dr. Walton's recent action in
his continuing struggle to
reinstate the Education
Department has certainly
brought the question to the
surface, but if the past is any
prophet, he will largely be
ignored.
It seems evident that the

administration will not
re-establish the Education
Department anytime in the near
future on any basis which has
thus far been proposed: setting
up a full-scale graduate
department is certainly a large
undertaking. To date, however,
the undergraduate need has not
been mentioned. Although the
current undergraduate needs are
met by the Evening College, the
little bit of red tape and the
inconvenience of evening classes
is undesirable.
Perhaps what we need is a
compromise department, one
that would offer only a very
basic course of study which
would be sufficient to meet most
state accreditation _requirements.
Such a department would be very
limited and not terribly hard to
implement, and it would meet
whatever undergraduate demand
there was without causing the
administration to become
apoplectic.
Will Fastie

To the Editors:
I would like to commend the
News-Letter for printing a public
service ad in the February 15th
edition that tells the whole story
about the availability of abortion
in Maryland and emphasizes the
fact that there are indeed
non-profit referral and
counselling services right in
Baltimore.
Profit-making referral agencies
have proliferated in the wake of
abortion law reform or repeal
throughout the country. These
agencies were outlawed in New
York by Attorney General
Lefkowitz last summer, but they
continue to flourish in
Pennsylvania, Maryland and
Washington, D.C. The agencies
advertising in the Hopkins
News-Letter and other college or
hip papers in this area have been
tested by Planned Parenthood
staffers. Although the degree of
sensitivity in the voice at the end
of the line did vary, the basic
'message stated by each agency
was "send us the money, and
we'll tell you where you can go
for an abortion." Little
attention, if any, was paid to the
uncertainty that the tester
expressed about having an
abortion, or in fact, whether or
not she was even pregnant. And
with the exception of one case,
when the agency was told that
the caller did not have any
money and was literally begging
for another resource that would
do the abortion for a lower price,
the caller was told that she would
have to get the money or get no
abortion.
And the.money: the fees were
anywhere from $25 to $100
higher than the going rates at
hospitals and free standing
clinics. In addition to this,
misinformation was very
common. When asked if there
was a free Clinic or a Planned
Parenthood in the city of
Baltimore that could help the
staffer who• was posing as a
scared college girl, she was told
that either she could only go to
Planned Parenthood if she were

feb 23, 1972/news-letter/page 3

Reading clockwise from top left: Robert D.H. Harvey,
chairman of the Board of Trustees, confers the Presidency of
the University to Dr. Muller, as Dr. Eisenhower prepares to
invest him with the presidential insignia; Dr. Muller gives his
inaugural address. On his right is the historic cane chair given to
the University by the Harvard Club of Maryland, a replica of
the President's chair of Harvard College; Dr. Muller and his
wife, Margie, greet guests at the reception following the
ceremony; Chief Marshal A. Edward Maumenee carries the
Presidential Mace, an ebony staff decorated with silver which
represents the role of the Arts and Sciences in man's cultural
development.Photos by Daniel Epstein.

page 4Inews-letterifeb 23, 1972

Muller becomes Hopkins' youngest president
Dr. Steven Muller, forty-four
years old, is the youngest man to
become Hopkins' president since
Daniel Coit Gilman took that
office nearly one hundred years
ago. Muller has spent much of his
life in university campuses.
With the exception of two
year's duty in the Army Signal
Corps, he has been connected
with a university—in one way or
another—since his undergraduate
days at UCLA. His university
experience has ranged from
undergraduate to his new post as
President, filling virtually every
slot in between.
He graduated from UCLA in
1948, travelling to Oxford as a
Rhodes Scholar, earning a B.
Litt. degree in 1951. Muller then
returned to the United States and
enrolled as a graduate student in
political science at Cornell.
In 1958, after two years in the
Army and a two year tenure as
assistant professor of political
science at Haverford College, he
received his Ph.D. from Cornell.
He joined the faculty of the
Cornell Government Department
that year. Many of the faculty
with whom Muller was associated

at Cornell felt that he had
foresaken his academic ability
when he turned from teaching to
administrative duties, one of his
former colleagues said. He served.
in the Cornell administration for'
nearly ten years.
InternationakStudies
In 1961, Muller took over as
director of the Cornell's
Vice-President for Public Affairs
during his last five years at the
New York school.
It was in that position that he
came to national attention during
the "Straight Crisis" at Cornell in
1969. Muller served as a
negotiator during the
confrontation which saw armed
students occupy the student
center. He was widely praised for
his actions at that time.
Muller came to Hopkins in
April, 1971 as Provost of the
University. During the nine
months before his election as
president, Muller served as
assistant to interim President
Milton Eisenhower.
During his days at UCLA,
Muller met his wife-to-be, the
former Margie Hellman. While he
studied at Oxford as a Rhodes

Med Plan to bring
community action
By MICHAEL BERKE
Dedication of the East
Baltimore Medital Plan medical
and dental clinics, Sunday, marks,
the Medical Institutions'
participation in affairs of the
local community.
The medical plan is operated
by the Johns Hopkins Medical
Institutions and the East
Baltimore Community.
Corporation. It provides prepaid,
group practice health care for
residents of Latrobe, Douglass,
Lafayette and Somerset Homes
housing projects.
Dr. Rogers, former dean of the
medical school ,.spoke at the
dedication at St. James and St.
John Roman Catholic Church,
Eager and Aisquith streets.
Rogers told a crowd of about
one hundred that "the
microcosm of East Baltimore is
representative of the health care
problems of inner cities."
"You who will work in the
center will have the spotlight
shown upon you," Rogers said.
The clinic will be a model for
solution of health care problems
in inner cities in the United
States.
"Obstacles to creating the
health care program were
formidable," he stated.
Defects in Mechanisms
"The negotiations you went
through reveal "appalling defects
in mechanisEis for financing
health care," Rogers told the
board. "It made particularly
evident the problems for those
who are black and those who are
poor," he continued.
The board had to contend
with five financing mechanisms
and twelve agencies' financing
restrictions in establishing the
center.
"A group of concerned human
beings learned to work together
for a common goal," Rogers said.
Residents of the neighborhood
surrounding the hospital and

executives of the Medical
Institutions are members of the
Board of Directors.
Do Say
"About three years ago I never
thought we'd get to the place
where we'd talk about each other
like that," said city councilman
Clarence H. "Do'. Burns, whc
presided at the dedication.
A ribbon cutting ceremony
and tour at the medical and
dental center followed the
dedication.

Scholar, she launched her career
in public relations, and they were
married in England in 1951.
While Muller was enrolled at
Cornell, she continued her career,
working as a free-lance writer,
advertising copy-writer, and
finally an assistant vice-president
of marketing for an Ithacarbank.
She is currently employed as
public relations officer for
Maryland National Bank.
Muller was born in Hamburg,
Germany in 1927. His family
moved to Los Angeles, California
in 1940, where he graduated
•as
from high school and entered
UCLA. His father, a lawyer and
judge in Germany, was employed
The Harveys, left, and the Mullers prepare to receive the line ofguests
as a translator

Kunstler brings politics to Towson
Speaking to an assembly of
200 students at Towson State,
Monday night, attorney William
Kunstler called the trial of
Arthur Turco "disgraceful and
unfathomable."
Kunstler defended Turco in
the trial which ended last
Monday with the acquittal of
Turco on charges of ordering the
execution of a Black Panther.
Turco, who spoke to the
students before Kunstler, denied
that he directed the killing when
he allegedly told a Black
Panther, "Do what you gotta
do."
Kunstler charged the State's
Prosecuting Attorney Milton
Allen with "calling confessed" to
the witness stand and with
producing witnesses to testify
against Turco who were
previously on the payroll of the
Baltimore City Police
Department's Intelligence
Division.
Commenting on the charges
against Turco and the means

employed by the prosecution,
the lawyer who defended the
Chicago Seven declared, "This
city is guilty of attempted
murder. In any decent society,
Milton Allen would have been
indicted, and the failure to do so
speaks louder than words."
Kunstler termed Allen a
"disgrace to the legal
profession."
Calling for an investigation of
the Police Department, Kunstler
criticized Baltimore's "supine
public which allows itself to be
driven and bullied by officials
who cheat, lie and murder in the
name ofjustice."
He continued, "Law like this
should not be respected but
destroyed."
Citing the absence of any
editorial comment in the city's
newspapers concerning the Turco
"pseudo-trial," Kunstler
characterized Baltimore as "a
moribund or dying community
whose citizens are all guilty
because of their indifference."

Kunstler compared the
indifferent people of Nazi
Germany who countenanced the
atrocities of Auschwitz to
Baltimoreans who remain silent
in face of Turco's plight.
"Inhumanity"
Noting his sudden fame as a
"New York streetfighter with a
lawbook" Turco traced his
original dissatisfaction with the
legal system to the "inhumanity"
he experienced in the New York
jails.
Owen Fenn, a member of the
People's Party of Baltimore
circulated a petition at the
beginning of the evening in hopes
of attracting 10,000 signatures to
place a Peace and Freedom Party
candidate on the Presidential
ballot. Fenn's offices,where the
petition can be signed, are
at 1 East 25th St.
There was also a plea for a
barrage of letters to be directed
at the Iranian Embassy in protest
of the recent string of political
executions in that State.

Hopkins hoop win clinches playoff berth
By MARK LEIFER
Credit Blue Jay basketball
Coach Gary Rupert with working
his second miracle in two years at
Hopkins. Rupert's charges made
it official Monday night by
whipping Franklin & Marshall at
Lancaster, 78-64, to clinch a
third place finish in the Middle
Atlantic Conference Southern
Division, thereby earning a berth
in the loop's postseason playoffs.
Climax
The victory climaxed an
unlikely success story that bears
a familiar ring for Blue Jay
basketball fans. Two weeks ago
the cagers' season mark stood at
2-13, hardly an awe-inspiring
ledger. A recent run of four
straight conference triumphs over
Ursinus, Dickinson, Moravian,
and F&M, however, has boosted
the Jays' conference record to
6-3, despite an 0-12 slate in
non-league play. Ironically, the
squad was 2-11 last season before
shocking three-time defending
MAC champ Muhlenberg, second
place Lebanon Valley, and tough
University division foe Drexel in
succession to start their climb to
fourth place. Hopkins nipped
heavily favored Muhlenberg,

Not to be overlooked by any

vanquishers of Hopkins, in the
opening round of the MAC
playoffs March 3-4, while
Lebanon Valley, 101-68 winner
over the Jays, takes on
Dickinson, 97-68 losers to
Hopkins. Should the Miracle Men
slip by the Pioneers, Rupert
maintains he won't fear a
rematch with the Flying
Dutchmen. "We're strong now;
we may raise some hell up
there."
